AmirsAmir's emotional outburst has his origin in previous events and incidences.
One factor is the situation in the restaurant before scene one.
Amir was racial profiled by a waiter of a restaurant (p. 34, l. 5).
Then it was not really a problem, Amir reacted souveransovereign and convinced with his perfect englishEnglish.
The next event was a newspaper article about him helping the supposed muslimMuslim imam (p. 43, l. 5).

The third event in scene three was much more dramatic for his job.
His boss did a background check on him and found out that he changed his muslimMuslim identity (p. 30, l. 10).
This trilogy of events in which he was disadvantaged because of his religion and ethnic background had a huge mental effect on Amir.
Now in this scene he fears to lose something again because of his religion and culture and this is why he becomes so emotional and aggressive.
Amir doesn't want to lose his wife to a jewishJewish person.
This three events bring back his antisemitism he learned as a child.
To conclude this key scene is the turning point of the play.
Amir falls back to old behavior patterns and antisemitism he was educated.
He loses relationships to his friends and his wife.
